title: 107_s1572
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Freedom Consolidation Act of 2001". Congress finds that full and active participants in the Partnership for Peace should be invited to become full NATO members in accordance with Article 10 of the NATO Treaty. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 called for the prompt admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO, and also aimed to include emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe. The NATO Enlargement Facilitation Act of 1996 called for the admission of Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia to NATO. In the European Security Act of 1998, Congress emphasized the importance of including emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe in NATO, beyond just the initial four countries mentioned. In 1998, the European Security Act highlighted the importance of including emerging democracies like Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria in NATO to enhance stability, freedom, and peace in Europe. At the Madrid Summit of the NATO Alliance in July 1997, Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic were invited to join the Alliance in the first round of NATO enlargement, with the expectation of extending further invitations to nations willing and able to meet membership criteria. At the Washington Summit in April 1999, NATO declared its intention to continue welcoming new members who can uphold the principles of the Treaty. At the Washington Summit in April 1999, NATO pledged to welcome new members who can uphold the Treaty's principles and contribute to peace and security in the Euro-Atlantic area. The communique stated that no European democratic country fulfilling the Treaty's objectives would be excluded from consideration for membership. In late 2002, NATO will hold a summit in Prague. In late 2002, NATO will hold a summit in Prague, Czech Republic, to decide on inviting additional emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe to join the Alliance in the next round of NATO enlargement. In May 2000 in Vilnius, Lithuania, several countries issued a statement declaring their commitment to NATO membership. In May 2000, several Eastern European countries declared their joint commitment to seeking NATO membership in the next round of enlargement. President George W. Bush expressed support for NATO membership for all European democracies seeking it, emphasizing security and freedom for new democracies in Eastern Europe. President George W. Bush supports NATO membership for all European democracies seeking security and freedom, emphasizing shared responsibilities and no nation being used as a pawn. He rejects trading away the fate of free European peoples and calls for advancing the cause of freedom at the Prague Summit. Former President William J. Clinton emphasized NATO's openness to all of Europe's emerging democracies at the Prague Summit in 1996, stating that no nation would be automatically excluded and no country outside NATO would have a veto. He warned against the reemergence of a gray zone of insecurity in Europe. SEC. 3. DECLARATIONS OF POLICY. Congress reaffirms its support for the continued enlargement of the NATO Alliance as expressed in previous acts and declarations, including those by President George W. Bush and former President William J. Clinton. Congress supports NATO enlargement as expressed by Presidents Bush and Clinton, urging allies to work towards this vision at the Prague Summit in 2002. Designation of Slovakia to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, in addition to other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovenia. Slovakia is designated as eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994, along with other countries like Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria. Latvia, Lithuania, and Bulgaria are eligible to receive assistance under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. The President can also designate other emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe for assistance under the same program. SEC. 5. Authorization of security assistance for countries designated under the NATO Participation Act of 1994. Authorization of Foreign Military Financing for fiscal year 2002: 
- $6,500,000 for Estonia
- $7,000,000 for Latvia
- $7,500,000 for Lithuania
- $8,500,000 for Slovakia
- $4,500,000 for Slovenia
- $10,000,000 for unspecified country In fiscal year 2002, foreign military financing authorizations include $8,500,000 for Slovakia, $4,500,000 for Slovenia, $10,000,000 for an unspecified country, and $11,500,000 for Romania. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 515 of the Security Assistance Act of 2000.
